message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A survey on LLM-based multi-agent systems: workflow, infrastructure, and challenges
Paper Abstract: Abstract The pursuit of more intelligent and credible autonomous systems, akin to human society, has been a long-standing endeavor for humans. Leveraging the exceptional reasoning and planning capabilities of large language models (LLMs), LLM-based agents have been proposed and have achieved remarkable success across a wide array of tasks. Notably, LLM-based multi-agent systems (MAS) are considered a promising pathway towards realizing general artificial intelligence that is equivalent to or surpasses human-level intelligence. In this paper, we present a comprehensive survey of these studies, offering a systematic review of LLM-based MAS. Adhering to the workflow of LLM-based multi-agent systems, we synthesize a general structure encompassing five key components: profile, perception, self-action, mutual interaction, and evolution. This unified framework encapsulates much of the previous work in the field. Furthermore, we illuminate the extensive applications of LLM-based MAS in two principal areas: problem-solving and world simulation. Finally, we discuss in detail several contemporary challenges and provide insights into potential future directions in this domain.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Large Language Models:

## Definition and Basics

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Historical Development

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Limitations

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

Links: [{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Category:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models"},{"title":"List of large language models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_large_language_models"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"Language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_model"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Writing articles with large language models/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Writing_articles_with_large_language_models/Archive_1"},{"title":"1.58-bit large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1.58-bit_large_language_model"},{"title":"Llama (language model) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LLaMA"},{"title":"Wikipedia talk:Large language models/Archive 5 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:Large_language_models/Archive_5"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Large Language Models:

## Definition and Basics

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

LLMs consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities and Applications

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering.(no content)LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability to generalize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and automated reasoning.

## Historical Development

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.(no content)Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

## Limitations

These models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

## Multi-Agent Systems

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy—where agents are at least partially independent and autonomous—and decentralization, where no agent is designated as controlling.

### Types of Agents

While multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

### Intelligence and Learning

Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Communication

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to common improvement, with example languages including Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about problem solving:

## Definition and Overview

Problem solving is the process of achieving a goal by overcoming obstacles, a frequent part of most activities.(no content)The term problem solving has a slightly different meaning depending on the discipline, such as a mental process in psychology and a computerized process in computer science.

## Types of Problems

There are two different types of problems: ill-defined and well-defined; well-defined problems have specific end goals and clearly expected solutions, while ill-defined problems do not. Additionally, simple problem solving (SPS) addresses one issue, whereas complex problem solving (CPS) involves multiple interrelated obstacles.

## Key Aspects of Problem Solving

The ability to understand what the end goal of the problem is, and what rules could be applied, represents the key to solving the problem.(no content)Sometimes a problem requires abstract thinking or coming up with a creative solution.

## The Problem-Solving Process

The process starts with problem finding and problem shaping, in which the problem is discovered and simplified, then generating possible solutions and evaluating them, and finally a solution is selected to be implemented and verified.

## Mental Obstacles

Problem-solving impediments include confirmation bias, mental set, and functional fixedness.

Links: [{"title":"Logic for Programming, Artificial Intelligence and Reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_for_Programming,_Artificial_Intelligence_and_Reasoning"},{"title":"Reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reasoning_system"},{"title":"Automated reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Knowledge representation and reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_representation_and_reasoning"},{"title":"Symbolic artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Commonsense reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_reasoning"},{"title":"Model-based reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-based_reasoning"},{"title":"Commonsense knowledge (artificial intelligence) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonsense_knowledge_(artificial_intelligence)"},{"title":"Knowledge-based systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge-based_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of artificial intelligence reasoning:

## What is AI Reasoning?

The study of automated reasoning helps produce computer programs that allow computers to reason completely, or nearly completely, automatically.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## Types of AI Reasoning

In information technology a reasoning system is a software system that generates conclusions from available knowledge using logical techniques such as deduction and induction. 

Several approaches to reasoning have been developed:

- **Symbolic AI**: Symbolic artificial intelligence is the term for the collection of all methods in artificial intelligence research that are based on high-level symbolic (human-readable) representations of problems, logic, and search.

- **Automated Theorem Proving**: The most developed subareas of automated reasoning are automated theorem proving (and the less automated but more pragmatic subfield of interactive theorem proving) and automated proof checking.

- **Commonsense Reasoning**: In artificial intelligence, commonsense reasoning is a human-like ability to make presumptions about the type and essence of ordinary situations humans encounter every day.

## Knowledge-Based Systems

All knowledge-based systems have two defining components: an attempt to represent knowledge explicitly, called a knowledge base, and a reasoning system that allows them to derive new knowledge, known as an inference engine.

AI reasoning remains an active and evolving field, with applications ranging from expert systems to complex problem-solving across various domains.

I've completed the web search for "Agent action artificial intelligence". Here's what I found:

## Key Findings

**Intelligent Agents in AI:**
In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

**Action Selection:**
Action selection is a way of characterizing the most basic problem of intelligent systems: what to do next.(no content)Search and planning are the subfields of artificial intelligence devoted to finding action sequences that achieve the agent's goals.

**Agentic AI:**
A specialized subset of intelligent agents, agentic AI (also known as an AI agent or simply agent), expands this concept by proactively pursuing goals, making decisions, and taking actions over extended periods.

**Agent Architecture Patterns:**
The search results reveal several architectural approaches including ReAct (Reason + Act), an extension of chain-of-thought prompting that queries the underlying model to explain its reasoning before taking any action.

**Practical Applications:**
A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.

The search results provide comprehensive information about intelligent agents, action selection mechanisms, and modern agentic AI systems currently in development.

Links: [{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Graphplan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphplan"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Automated_Planning_and_Scheduling"},{"title":"AI-driven design automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AI-driven_design_automation"},{"title":"Partial-order planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial-order_planning"},{"title":"Reactive planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reactive_planning"},{"title":"Category:Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Stanford Research Institute Problem Solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanford_Research_Institute_Problem_Solver"}]

Here are the search results for "Automated planning artificial intelligence":

## Overview

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

## Key Approaches

The field employs several planning methodologies:

- **Hierarchical Planning**: An alternative language for describing planning problems is that of hierarchical task networks, in which a set of tasks is given, and each task can be either realized by a primitive action or decomposed into a set of other tasks.

- **Partial-Order Planning**: Partial-order planning is an approach to automated planning that maintains a partial ordering between actions and only commits ordering between actions when forced to, that is, ordering of actions is partial.

- **Reactive Planning**: In artificial intelligence, reactive planning denotes a group of techniques for action selection by autonomous agents. They operate in a timely fashion and hence can cope with highly dynamic and unpredictable environments.

## Important Planning Systems and Languages

The Stanford Research Institute Problem Solver, known by its acronym STRIPS, is an automated planner developed by Richard Fikes and Nils Nilsson in 1971 at SRI International.(no content)The Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL) is an attempt to standardize Artificial Intelligence (AI) planning languages. It was first developed by Drew McDermott and his colleagues in 1998 mainly to make the 1998/2000 International Planning Competition (IPC) possible.(no content)Graphplan is an algorithm for automated planning developed by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst in 1995.

I've completed a web search for "Computer simulation world." Here are the key findings:

## What is Computer Simulation?

Computer simulation is the running of a mathematical model on a computer, the model being designed to represent the behaviour of, or the outcome of, a real-world or physical system.

## Applications and Uses

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)Simulation is used in many contexts, such as simulation of technology for performance tuning or optimizing, safety engineering, testing, training, education, and video games.

## Historical Context

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Notable Examples

Computer simulation games such as World of Warcraft are played by millions of people around the world. Additionally, notable computer simulations used in science include Donella Meadows' World3 used in the Limits to Growth, James Lovelock's Daisyworld and Thomas Ray's Tierra.

## Simulated Reality Concept

A simulated reality is an approximation of reality created in a simulation, usually in a set of circumstances in which something is engineered to appear real when it is not.

Computer simulations have become a useful tool for the mathematical modeling of many natural systems in physics, astrophysics, climatology, chemistry, biology and manufacturing, as well as human systems in economics, psychology, social science, health care and engineering.(no content)Simulation is used in many contexts, such as simulation of technology for performance tuning or optimizing, safety engineering, testing, training, education, and video games.

## Historical Context

Computer simulation developed hand-in-hand with the rapid growth of the computer, following its first large-scale deployment during the Manhattan Project in World War II to model the process of nuclear detonation.

## Notable Examples

Computer simulation games such as World of Warcraft are played by millions of people around the world. Additionally, notable computer simulations used in science include Donella Meadows' World3 used in the Limits to Growth, James Lovelock's Daisyworld and Thomas Ray's Tierra.

## Simulated Reality Concept

A simulated reality is an approximation of reality created in a simulation, usually in a set of circumstances in which something is engineered to appear real when it is not.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about perception in artificial intelligence:

## Overview

Machine perception is the capability of a computer system to interpret data in a manner that is similar to the way humans use their senses to relate to the world around them.(no content)Perception is one of the traditional goals of AI research, alongside learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, and support for robotics.

## Key Applications

The field includes speech recognition, image classification, facial recognition, object recognition, object tracking, and robotic perception.(no content)The end goal of machine perception is to give machines the ability to see, feel and perceive the world as humans do and therefore for them to be able to explain in a human way why they are making their decisions, to warn us when it is failing and more importantly, the reason why it is failing.

## Specific Types of Machine Perception

Machine perception encompasses multiple sensory modalities:

- **Machine Touch**: Machine touch is an area of machine perception where tactile information is processed by a machine or computer. Applications include tactile perception of surface properties and dexterity whereby tactile information can enable intelligent reflexes and interaction with the environment.

- **Machine Olfaction**: Scientists are developing computers known as machine olfaction which can recognize and measure smells as well. Airborne chemicals are sensed and classified with a device sometimes known as an electronic nose.

## Future Challenges

Future hurdles that the science of machine perception still has to overcome include embodied cognition—the theory that cognition is a full body experience, and therefore can only exist, and therefore be measured and analyzed, in fullness if all required human abilities and processes are working together through a mutually aware and supportive systems network.

Links: [{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Ben Goertzel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ben_Goertzel"},{"title":"Generative artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AGI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AGI"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Conference on Artificial General Intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_on_Artificial_General_Intelligence"},{"title":"Superintelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superintelligence"},{"title":"Technological singularity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_singularity"},{"title":"Strong AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_AI"},{"title":"Existential risk from artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existential_risk_from_artificial_intelligence"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Artificial General Intelligence:

## Definition

Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks. Unlike narrow AI systems that excel at specific tasks, an AGI system can generalise knowledge, transfer skills between domains, and solve novel problems without task‑specific reprogramming.

## Key Characteristics

A machine with artificial general intelligence would be able to solve a wide variety of problems with breadth and versatility similar to human intelligence.(no content)The concept does not, in principle, require the system to be an autonomous agent; a static model—such as a highly capable large language model—or an embodied robot could both satisfy the definition so long as human‑level breadth and proficiency are achieved.

## Related Concepts

Artificial superintelligence (ASI) would outperform the best human abilities across every domain by a wide margin. Additionally, transformative AI relates to AI having a large impact on society, for example, similar to the agricultural or industrial revolution.

## Current Status and Timeline

In September 2025, a review of surveys of scientists and industry experts from the last 15 years reported that most agreed that artificial general intelligence (AGI), a level well below technological singularity, will occur before the year 2100. More specifically, current surveys of AI researchers are predicting AGI around 2040.

## Industry Goals

Creating AGI is a stated goal of AI technology companies such as OpenAI, Google, xAI, and Meta.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the LLM-based multi-agent systems survey paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `survey`

This is a literature review and systematic survey of LLM-based multi-agent systems, not a novel contribution.
